value.name: Who are the Houthi rebels behind attacks on ships in Red Sea?
value.description: The rebels have attacked Saudi Arabia, the UAE and most recently Israel with missiles before the clashes in the Red Sea erupted. The joint operation on Monday comes after US and UK warships and jets hit more than 60 targets in 28 locations on January 11.

value.name: NHS bill could be cut by £10bn by cracking down on waste Labour claim
value.description: Labour also claimed £1.7bn was being wasted due to beds being blocked by people who are well enough to leave hospital but cannot because of a lack of community care. However, the party does not spell out how it would deal with chronic social care failures in the UK.

value.name: Labour's David Lammy says he would work with Donald Trump - despite calling him a 'neo-Nazi-sympathising sociopath'
value.description: Mr Lammy, Labour's shadow foreign secretary, repeatedly criticised Mr Trump during his first presidency but said he would work with him if the pair ended up at either end of the so-called special relationship.

value.name: Putin election campaign presents boxes filled with petitions backing his run
value.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin’s campaign staff have unveiled scores of boxes filled with signed petitions supporting his run in the March presidential election – a vote he is almost certain to win. Mr Putin, although closely tied to the dominant ...

value.name: The BBC faces an uphill battle for public’s trust in a monumental year
value.description: “The BBC must be destroyed in order to be saved,” writes the iconoclastic former BBC royal correspondent Michael Cole. He suggests a subscription service for BBC News, including documentaries and Radio 4, with a separate sub charged for the BBC’s music and culture output.

value.name: Fresh UK and US airstrikes on Houthi targets to ‘deal another blow’ to militants

value.name: Culture Secretary Javid is under fire from SNP

value.name: Norman Jewison, Fiddler On The Roof and Moonstruck director, dies aged 97
value.description: Norman Jewison, the Canadian-born director whose Hollywood films ranged from Doris Day comedies and Moonstruck to social dramas such as the Oscar-winning In The Heat Of The Night, has died aged 97.

value.name: US and UK carry out fresh strikes on Houthis
value.description: The UK and the US have once again carried out joint airstrikes against Houthi targets in Yemen. Officials say the US and UK took out Houthi missile storage sites and launchers, in the second set of co-ordinated strikes against the Iran-backed militants.

value.name: Chief Whip To Warn Tory MPs Who Rebelled On Rwanda
value.description: The Conservative Party witnessed its biggest rebellion in years after 60 MPs called on Rishi Sunak to tighten his grip on the Rwanda legislation.

value.description: Former Cop26 president abstains from vote saying bill breaks UK’s promise to phase out fossil fuels

value.name: The latest on Israel's war in Gaza
value.description: Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu rejected Hamas' conditions for an end to the war in exchange for the release of hostages held in Gaza as he faces increasing public pressure to bring the captives home.

value.name: Voter ID rules could be seen to benefit Conservatives, warns elections watchdog
value.description: John Pullinger says forcing voters to carry identification could disenfranchise certain groups at the general election

value.name: Calls for political action to address staggering increase in porn addiction among young people
value.description: Mental health and addiction clinic, Paracelsus Recovery, has reported a 150 per cent increase in people being treated for porn addiction between 2019 and 2023.

value.name: Measles cases on the rise + Trump's big week
value.description: And in the US, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has dropped out the race to become the Republican presidential nominee, endorsing Mr Trump. Is the race to challenge Joe Biden effectively over? BBC US Special Correspondent, Katty Kay, brings us the latest from the campaign trail.

value.name: Concerns raised as North Sea oil proposals clear first Commons hurdle
value.description: A Government bid to maximise North Sea oil and gas production has cleared its first Commons test, amid Tory criticism and warnings of “sleepless nights” over the proposals.

value.name: Blow for Rishi Sunak as Rwanda plan suffers first defeat in House of Lords
value.description: The House of Lords has defied Rishi Sunak to vote against the ratification of the UK's new treaty with Rwanda - in what could prove a damaging development for the Safety of Rwanda Bill. The upper house was voting following a report last week that recommended the treaty not be ratified.
